Award.AwardTitle: Making Simulated Biology Laboratories Accessible to Visually-Impaired Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Biological Sciences (61)

Incorporation of audio and tactile tools for making simulated experiments in virtual biology laboratories accessible to blind and low vision students are being explored. Students and consultants with visual impairments are participating in the development and testing of different techniques for presenting screen information and for allowing interactions with simulations.

Intellectual Merit: The immediate goal is the development of a set of techniques that will allow participation of a more diverse set of students in inquiry-based biology labs, including visually impaired students for whom most traditional biology labs are inaccessible. Ultimately, this focused project should help improve simulated laboratories for all students.

Broader Impact: The techniques being developed are breaking down some of the challenges facing those with visual impairments in the pursuit of scientific careers. In addition to directly benefiting the students who use the Simbiotic labs, the results of this project will be published in both technical and non-technical forms to inform and inspire other educational software developers.

This project is partially supported by funds from the Research in Disabilities Education program and the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Emerging Frontiers Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored ways of making simulation-based virtual laboratories in biology accessible to blind and low-vision students. We built the project around a very popular virtual laboratory called Isle Royale. The Isle Royale lab uses a famous ecological study about moose and wolf population dynamics to help students learn important concepts in population dynamics.

In this phase I study, we focused on letting blind and low-vision students experience and learn from Isle Royale by exploring ways of using sound to represent data on the key graph in the lab. This graph plots the populations of moose and of wolves on the island over time. We called our sound-based graphs "Audible Graphs". We followed two tracks to investigate how to make effective Audible Graphs.

Audible Isle Royale

The first was to create an example of an Audible Graph within a simplified version of the lab. The Audible Graph has keyboard commands which let students select which species to plot on the graph, play sections of the graph, rewind, and play the graph slower or faster. Each data set on the graph has a sound associated with it which changes depending on the value of the data. The graph also reads out timestamps periodically along the time axis. To accompany this, we needed to add in the ability for on screen instructions to be read out using a keyboard interface, and to add an audible navigation menu that allows users to navigate around the lab as well as hear and select all the various commands that control the simulations and the Audible Graphs.

We tested an early prototype of the Audible Isle Royale lab in a summer camp put on by the National Federation for the Blind, with a very enthusiastic response from the students there. We plan to complete an alpha version of the lab in the near future (pending final analysis from the second part of this study, see below) and will be testing this by distributing to schools that already use the Isle Royale lab as an alternative lab for blind and low vision students, as well as incorporating some of the techniques we developed into SimBio's other labs, and writing a design research paper on our findings.

Audible Graph Survey

The second track in this study was to create an audible survey to look for where Audible Graphs are likely to be most useful. The survey was divided into five parts.

1. Interpreting single simple data sets on a graph through audio alone.

2. Distinguishing two independent curves on one graph.

3. Distinguishing the temporal relationship between two simple curves on one graph.

4. Distinguishing a relationship between two more complex data sets on one graph.

5. Collecting feedback on sound preferences, and any general comments on the approach.

In all parts, we asked whether certain types of sounds made the interpretation easier than others

Close to 500 participants took the survey, of which approximately 1/4 were blind or low-vision. Our initial results are encouraging for the approach, and point to some ways that Audible Graphs could be made more effective. Although distinguishing two independent curves on a graph does not appear to be possible, the other three types of graphs we tested all seem to be accessible with Audible Graphs. Moreover, we saw evidence that training on the Audible Graphs helps people improve their ability to distinguish curves on the graphs. We are preparing a paper on our results from this survey.
